CAVORT.deftext:
to make merry, prance, jump about

To CAVORT is to make merry, usually by jumping and dancing about. The word was originally used about a horse and its rider.

“The mother dog looked on calmly while her puppies CAVORTED in the tall grass.”

“We enjoyed watching the children CAVORTING on the beach.”

“The students CAVORTED on the steps of the school, happy to be going home at last.”

CONCEDE.deftext:
to admit, acknowledge; to grant, surrender

CONCEDE has two different meanings. To CONCEDE something is to admit that it is true.

“After a long debate Ed finally CONCEDED the point and said we were right.”

“We CONCEDED that we had been a bit hasty in criticizing her.”

The word can also mean to grant or surrender.

“When Jim injured his foot he had to CONCEDE the match to his opponent.”

“As part of the peace treaty they CONCEDED all the territory they had won in the war.”

The most common mistake in the Pretest is to choose deny as the meaning of CONCEDE. This is a confusion of a word with its opposite. People who choose deny as the meaning of CONCEDE perhaps know that CONCEDE has something to do with the truth, but aren’t exactly sure what.

Other forms of the word: CONCESSION, n.

INTEGRAL.deftext:
necessary for completeness, essential

INTEGRAL is from a Latin word meaning whole, entire, also the source of the word integer. An integer, in arithmetic, is a whole number (1, 2, 3, 4 . . .) as opposed to a fraction. Something that is INTEGRAL to something else is necessary for its completeness.

“This piece is INTEGRAL to the machine. If you remove it, nothing will work.”

INTEGRAL is often found in the phrase “an INTEGRAL part of,” which means a necessary or essential part of.

“Learning vocabulary is an INTEGRAL part of education; without words you can’t read.”

DOTING.deftext:
: overly fond; weak-minded

To DOTE on someone is to show excessive affection for him.

“Our grandmother DOTES on us; she’ll give us anything we want.”

DOTING is the adjective from DOTE, and means “showing too much fondness.”

“The DOTING parents couldn’t keep their eyes off their new baby.”

“The DOTING husband brought his wife flowers every night.”

In another sense, DOTING is sometimes used to mean weak-minded, especially from old age. This sense is particularly found in the noun DOTAGE, which means “feebleness of mind resulting from old age.”

“In his DOTAGE his mind started to wander and it was hard to understand him.”

Other forms of the word: DOTAGE, n. DOTE, v.

INTERIM.deftext:
temporary, provisional

INTERIM comes directly from a Latin word which means “in the meantime,” meanwhile. INTERIM is used as a noun in the phrase “in the INTERIM,” which means exactly the same as the Latin word. As an adjective, INTERIM means “done or occurring in the meantime,” temporary.

“They issued an INTERIM report until the new set of figures came in and they could make it final.”

“They set up an INTERIM government to rule while the new constitution was being written.”

LACKLUSTER.deftext:
dull, uninspired

Luster is brightness, the glow of a polished surface. Something which is LACKLUSTER lacks luster or brightness; it is dull, uninspired. The word is especially used about expressions, actions, events, and the like.

“She always had a LACKLUSTER expression on her face, as if she weren’t interested in anything.”

“It was a LACKLUSTER performance—nothing very good about it, nothing very bad about it.”

Many people think LACKLUSTER means terrible. LACKLUSTER, however, is not that strong. It merely means dull, uninteresting, lacking brilliance.

CONVULSION.deftext:
a fit, disturbance, upheaval

To CONVULSE is to shake violently.

“California was CONVULSED by an earthquake.”

CONVULSION is the noun from CONVULSE. A CONVULSION is a violent shaking or disturbance, particularly the uncontrolled irregular movements of the muscles during a fit. In this case the word is usually used in the plural.

“The child went into CONVULSIONS after she swallowed the poison.”

A CONVULSION can also be any kind of disturbance or upheaval.

“Constant social CONVULSIONS kept the nation in a state of chaos for years.”

The most popular wrong answers on the Pretest are illness and urge. A CONVULSION can be caused by an illness, but its meaning is much more specific. The choice of urge is probably due in most cases to a confusion between CONVULSION and compulsion, which is a strong urge.

Other forms of the word: CONVULSE, v. CONVULSIVE, adj.

PLAUSIBLE.deftext:
likely, apparently reasonable

Something that is PLAUSIBLE has the appearance of being true. A PLAUSIBLE argument sounds true and makes sense, even if in fact it is not true.

“He gave the teacher a PLAUSIBLE reason about why he hadn’t done his homework.”

“Her excuse sounded PLAUSIBLE at the time, but later on we found out she had been lying.”

The opposite of PLAUSIBLE is IMPLAUSIBLE, which mean unlikely, improbable.

“The account of his adventures sounded IMPLAUSIBLE, but in fact that was exactly what had happened.”

Other forms of the word: PLAUSIBILITY, n.

WHIMSICAL.deftext:
playful, fanciful, fantastic

WHIMSICAL is an adjective from WHIMSY. WHIMSY is odd or fanciful humor, or the product of such humor.

“He is full of WHIMSY; he always has such fanciful ideas.”

Someone or something that is WHIMSICAL is full of such odd notions or behavior.

“Although usually very serious, he could sometimes be very strange and WHIMSICAL.”

“Her WHIMSICAL behavior bewildered everyone. She was always doing the oddest things at the most unexpected times.”

“He told the children a WHIMSICAL story about how elves paint the grass green.”

Other forms of the word: WHIM, n. WHIMSY, n.

ABORIGINE.deftext:
a native, original inhabitant

Note the pronunciation. The e is sounded.

You can see the word origin in ABORIGINE. ABORIGINE comes from the Latin phrase ab origine, which means “from the beginning.” An ABORIGINE is one of the native people of a region or country. ABORIGINES have lived in a particular region “from the beginning.” They were the very first people to come into the region from somewhere else and settle there.

“The colonists arriving from across the sea found the ABORIGINES friendly and willing to share their land.”

“The invading tribe conquered the ABORIGINES and made them leave their native land.”

The word ABORIGINES is also used for the original flowers and animals in a particular region.

Other forms of the word: ABORIGINAL, adj.

CEREBRAL.deftext:
mental, intellectual

The CEREBRUM is a part of the brain. The basic meaning of CEREBRAL is “of the CEREBRUM or the brain.” CEREBRAL palsy is a disability caused by damage to the brain. When used about people or their activities, CEREBRAL means intellectual, as opposed to emotional. A CEREBRAL person mainly uses his reasoning and critical powers, and not his intuitions or instincts.

“He is a CEREBRAL writer; his stories aren’t exciting, but they give a lot of food for thought.”

INCITE.deftext:
to stir up, spur on, urge on, arouse

To INCITE is to stir up, to urge somebody to do something. Usually the word suggests that something bad is being stirred up.

“Her fiery speeches INCITED them to riot.”

“His tales of gold hidden inside INCITED the crowd to break into the building and steal everything they could find.”

“The assassination of the prince INCITED violence between the two warring parties.”

The noun from INCITE is INCITEMENT, something that stirs people up.

“The umpire’s one bad call was enough of an INCITEMENT for the crowd to boo him for the rest of the game.”

Other forms of the word: INCITEMENT, n.

COSMOPOLITAN.deftext:
worldwide, universal, worldly

COSMOPOLITAN comes from two Greek words. The cosmo part of the word means world or universe; it is also found in the words COSMOS and COSMONAUT. The polit part means citizen; it also appears in politics and police. COSMOPOLITAN is used about people or things that are at home all over the world. It is especially applied to people who are free from local prejudices or interests, who have a broad, sophisticated outlook.

“Jim has a COSMOPOLITAN background; he lived in six different countries before he was twelve.”

“He believed that statesmen should have a COSMOPOLITAN point of view when trying to solve world problems.”

DERIVATION.deftext:
source, origin

To DERIVE means to take or obtain, especially from a source.

“We DERIVE great pleasure from watching television.”

“The name of this town is DERIVED from an Indian word.”

The DERIVATION of something is its source or origin.

“What is the DERIVATION of the custom of collecting candy on Halloween?”

DERIVATION is used especially about the development of a word from earlier words.

“Many English words are of Latin DERIVATION.”

“The teacher explained the DERIVATION of the word amateur.”

Other forms of the word: DERIVATIVE, adj. DERIVE, v.

FRACAS.deftext:
a disturbance, uproar, noisy quarrel, fight, brawl

A FRACAS is a noisy disturbance, an uproar. The word is generally used about people fighting or disagreeing with one another.

“A FRACAS erupted among some spectators who had been drinking.”

“Two policemen were injured trying to end the FRACAS.”

“A nice party suddenly became a FRACAS when everyone started arguing about politics.”

A FRACAS is smaller and less serious than a riot, but larger and usually more violent than a quarrel.

questions.prompt: Would a stubborn person enjoy CONCEDING something?
Is the engine an INTEGRAL part of a car?
Would a DOTING father be proud of his children?
Will an INTERIM plan always be used?
Would a LACKLUSTER game be very exciting?
Could a WHIMSICAL story be amusing?
Were the Pilgrims ABORIGINES in America?
Is falling in love a CEREBRAL activity?
Would a raise in pay sometimes INCITE people to work harder?
Would a COSMOPOLITAN newspaper contain just local news?
Could people get hurt in a FRACAS?
We were so excited we CAVORTED through the halls of the school.
It was certain that he was going to lose, but he refused to CONCEDE defeat.
The idea that there was intelligent life on other planets was INTEGRAL to his theory about the universe.
The DOTING boy stopped six different places on his way home from school.
This is just an INTERIM solution to the problem; we'll have to come up with something better before long.
Her dancing is brilliant, but her singing is LACKLUSTER.
The comedian's jokes CONVULSED us with laughter; we laughed so hard our sides were aching.
He told an IMPLAUSIBLE tale about a trip he took to Mars.
We heard a WHIMSICAL story about bloodshed, torture, and death.
The ABORIGINES could not defend their island against the invaders.
He suffered a CEREBRAL in his leg.
The general INCITED the private for outstanding bravery.
Her COSMOPOLITAN interests took her to Europe at least once a year.
She DERIVED a great deal of satisfaction from seeing her son graduate from college.
I was afraid the meeting would turn into a FRACAS if people lost their tempers.
